targets.query: SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean("usage_iowait"), 1s) FROM "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /^$server$/ AND "cpu" = 'cpu-total' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval) fill(null)
select mean(usage_user) as user from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = 'cpu-total' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_system) as system from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = 'cpu-total' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_softirq) as softirq from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = 'cpu-total' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_steal) as steal from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = 'cpu-total' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_nice) as nice from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = 'cpu-total' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_irq) as irq from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = 'cpu-total' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_iowait) as iowait from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = 'cpu-total' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_guest) as guest from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = 'cpu-total' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_guest_nice) as guest_nice from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = 'cpu-total' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(load1) as short from "system" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), * ORDER BY asc
select mean(load5) as medium from "system" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), * ORDER BY asc
select mean(load15) as long from "system" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), * ORDER BY asc
select mean(running) as running from "processes" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(blocked) as blocked from "processes" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(sleeping) as sleeping from "processes" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(stopped) as stopped from "processes" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(zombies) as zombies from "processes" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(paging) as paging from "processes" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(unknown) as unknown from "processes" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(total) as total from "mem" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(used) as used from "mem" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(cached) as cached from "mem" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(free) as free from "mem" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(buffered) as buffered from "mem" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(context_switches),1s)as "context switches"  FROM "kernel" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(processes_forked),1s) as forks FROM "kernel" WHERE "host" =~ /^$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host fill(null)
SELECT mean("file-max") as max FROM "linux_sysctl_fs" WHERE "host" =~ /^$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host fill(null)
SELECT mean("file-nr") as opened FROM "linux_sysctl_fs" WHERE "host" =~ /^$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host fill(null)
select mean(usage_user) as user from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = '$cpu' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_system) as system from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = '$cpu' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_softirq) as softirq from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = '$cpu' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_steal) as steal from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = '$cpu' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_nice) as nice from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = '$cpu' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_irq) as irq from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = '$cpu' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_iowait) as iowait from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = '$cpu' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_guest) as guest from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = '$cpu' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(usage_guest_nice) as guest_nice from "cpu" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ and cpu = '$cpu' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(tcp_close) as CLOSED from "netstat" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(tcp_close_wait) as CLOSE_WAIT from "netstat" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(tcp_closing) as CLOSING from "netstat" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(tcp_established) as ESTABLISHED from "netstat" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(tcp_fin_wait1) as FIN_WAIT1 from "netstat" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(tcp_fin_wait2) as FIN_WAIT2 from "netstat" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(tcp_last_ack) as LAST_ACK from "netstat" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(tcp_syn_recv) as SYN_RECV from "netstat" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(tcp_syn_sent) as SYN_SENT from "netstat" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(tcp_time_wait) as TIME_WAIT from "netstat" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(tcp_estabresets), 1s) FROM "net" WHERE "host" =~ /^$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval) fill(null)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(tcp_estabresets), 1s) FROM "net" WHERE "host" =~ /^$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval) fill(null)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(tcp_estabresets), 1s) FROM "net" WHERE "host" =~ /^$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval) fill(null)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(tcp_estabresets), 1s) FROM "net" WHERE "host" =~ /^$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval) fill(null)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(tcp_estabresets), 1s) FROM "net" WHERE "host" =~ /^$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval) fill(null)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(tcp_estabresets), 1s) FROM "net" WHERE "host" =~ /^$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval) fill(null)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(tcp_estabresets), 1s) FROM "net" WHERE "host" =~ /^$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval) fill(null)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(tcp_outrsts), 1s) FROM "net" WHERE "host" =~ /^$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval) fill(null)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(tcp_activeopens), 1s) FROM "net" WHERE "host" =~ /^$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval) fill(null)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(tcp_passiveopens), 1s) FROM "net" WHERE "host" =~ /^$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval) fill(null)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(udp_indatagrams), 1s) as "in datagrams" FROM "net" WHERE host =~ /$server/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), * fill(none)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(udp_outdatagrams), 1s) as "out datagrams" FROM "net" WHERE host =~ /$server/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), * fill(none)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(bytes_recv),1s)*8 as "in"  FROM "net" WHERE host =~ /$server/ AND interface =~ /$netif/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), * fill(none)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(bytes_sent),1s)*8 as "out" FROM "net" WHERE host =~ /$server/ AND interface =~ /$netif/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), * fill(none)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(packets_recv), 1s) as "in" FROM "net" WHERE host =~ /$server/ AND interface =~ /$netif/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), * fill(none)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(packets_sent), 1s) as "out" FROM "net" WHERE host =~ /$server/ AND interface =~ /$netif/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), * fill(none)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(drop_in), 1s) as "in" FROM "net" WHERE host =~ /$server/ AND interface =~ /$netif/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host,interface fill(none)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(drop_out), 1s) as "out" FROM "net" WHERE host =~ /$server/ AND interface =~ /$netif/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host,interface fill(none)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(err_in), 1s) as "in" FROM "net" WHERE host =~ /$server/ AND interface =~ /$netif/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host,interface fill(none)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(err_out), 1s) as "out" FROM "net" WHERE host =~ /$server/ AND interface =~ /$netif/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host,interface fill(none)
select non_negative_derivative(mean(in)) as in from "swap" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select non_negative_derivative(mean(out)) as out from "swap" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(used) as used from "swap" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
select mean(total) as total from "swap" WHERE host =~ /$server$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), host ORDER BY asc
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(reads),1s) as "read" FROM "diskio" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ AND "name" =~ /$disk$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(writes),1s) as "write" FROM "diskio" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ AND "name" =~ /$disk$/  AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(read_bytes),1s) as "read" FROM "diskio" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ AND "name" =~ /$disk$/  AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(write_bytes),1s) as "write" FROM "diskio" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ AND "name" =~ /$disk$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(read_time),1s) as "read" FROM "diskio" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ AND "name" =~ /$disk$/  AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean(write_time),1s) as "write" FROM "diskio" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ AND "name" =~ /$disk$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), *
select mean(total) AS total from "disk" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ AND "path" =~ /^$mountpoint$/AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), "host", "path"
select mean(used) as used from "disk" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/ AND "path" =~ /^$mountpoint$/AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), "host", "path"
SELECT mean(inodes_used) as "used" FROM "disk" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/  AND "path" =~ /^$mountpoint$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), "host", "path"
SELECT mean(inodes_free) + mean(inodes_used) as "total" FROM "disk" WHERE "host" =~ /$server$/  AND "path" =~ /^$mountpoint$/ AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($interval), "host", "path"

panels.description: This metric measures the average CPU utilization across all the containers in a given Pod. It represents the overall CPU utilization of the Pod, including all the containers running within it.
panels.title: Pod CPU Usage

panels.description: This metric measures the memory utilization across all the containers in a given Pod. It represents the overall memory utilization of the Pod, including all the containers running within it.
panels.title: Pod Used RAM

targets.legendFormat: Used CPU (ratio) for container {{k8s_container_name}} running on {{instance}}

coralogix.metadata.applicationName:"kube-system" AND coralogix.metadata.subsystemName:"kube-events"

targets.expr: avg((avg (k8s_pod_memory_working_set_By{k8s_namespace_name=~"$namespace", k8s_pod_name=~"$pod"}) by (k8s_pod_name))/ on (k8s_pod_name)(avg (k8s_pod_memory_usage_By{k8s_namespace_name=~"$namespace", k8s_pod_name=~"$pod"}) by (k8s_pod_name))*100) by (k8s_pod_name)

options.content:
SYNTHETIC MONITORING
STATUS DO WEBSITE: {{#if (eq data.[0].[0].Value 1)}}UP{{else}}DOWN{{/if}}
options.defaultContent: The query didn't return any results.
options.styles:
body {
  margin: 0; /* Remove margens padrão do corpo */
  padding: 0; /* Remove padding padrão do corpo */
  font-family: Arial, sans-serif; /* Define a família de fontes para o corpo do texto */
  background-color: #f0f0f0; /* Cor de fundo para o corpo da página */
  display: flex; /* Usa o modelo de layout flexbox para o corpo */
  justify-content: center; /* Centraliza o conteúdo na horizontal */
  align-items: center; /* Centraliza o conteúdo na vertical */
  min-height: 100vh; /* Altura mínima da tela inteira */
}

.container {
  display: flex; /* Usa o modelo de layout flexbox para o container */
  align-items: center; /* Centraliza verticalmente os elementos dentro do container */
  background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5); /* Cor de fundo semi-transparente do container */
  padding: 5px; /* Espaçamento interno de 20 pixels dentro do container */
  border-radius: 10px 10px 10px 50px; /* Borda arredondada com raios específicos para cada canto */
  box-shadow: 0 4px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2); /* Sombra com deslocamento de 0 no eixo x, 4px no eixo y, cor rgba */
  width: 100%; /* Largura do container ajustada conforme necessário */
  max-width: 100%; /* Largura máxima para limitar o tamanho em telas muito largas */
  margin: 0 auto; /* Centraliza o container na horizontal com margens automáticas */
  background-image: url('https://zabbixacademy.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/fundo-banner-01.png'); /* Imagem de fundo do container */
  background-position: center; /* Posiciona a imagem de fundo no centro */
  background-repeat: no-repeat; /* Impede que a imagem de fundo seja repetida */
  background-size: cover; /* Redimensiona a imagem de fundo para cobrir todo o container */
}

.title {
  flex: 1; /* Ocupa o espaço restante disponível dentro do container */
  font-size: 2rem; /* Tamanho da fonte */
  font-weight: bold; /* Texto em negrito */
  color: #ffffff; /* Cor do texto branca */
  text-shadow: 2px 2px 4px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5); /* Sombra no texto */
  text-align: center; /* Centraliza o texto horizontalmente */
  margin: 0; /* Remove margens padrão do título */
}

.status {
  font-size: 1.5rem; /* Tamanho da fonte */
  color: #ffffff; /* Cor do texto branca */
  text-shadow: 2px 2px 4px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5); /* Sombra no texto */
  text-align: right; /* Alinha o texto à direita */
}

.value {
  display: inline-block; /* Transforma o elemento em bloco com linha */
  padding: 5px 15px; /* Espaçamento interno de 5px superior/inferior e 15px esquerda/direita */
  border-radius: 5px; /* Borda arredondada com raio de 5 pixels */
}

.value.up {
  background-color: #00ff00; /* Fundo verde para valor 'up' */
  color: #000; /* Cor do texto preto */
}

.value.down {
  background-color: #ff0000; /* Fundo vermelho para valor 'down' */
  color: #fff; /* Cor do texto branca */
}

.image-container {
  margin-right: 10px; /* Espaçamento à direita do contêiner de imagem */
}

.image-container img {
  max-width: auto; /* Largura máxima da imagem dentro do contêiner de imagem */
  height: 60px; /* Altura automática da imagem para manter a proporção */
  border-radius: 10px; /* Borda arredondada com raio de 10 pixels na imagem */
}

panels.description:
**MySQL Uptime**

The amount of time since the last restart of the MySQL server process.
panels.title: MySQL Uptime

panels.description:
**Current QPS**

Based on the queries reported by MySQL's ``SHOW STATUS`` command, it is the number of statements executed by the server within the last second. This variable includes statements executed within stored programs, unlike the Questions variable. It does not count 
``COM_PING`` or ``COM_STATISTICS`` commands.
panels.title: Current QPS

panels.description:
**InnoDB Buffer Pool Size**

InnoDB maintains a storage area called the buffer pool for caching data and indexes in memory.  Knowing how the InnoDB buffer pool works, and taking advantage of it to keep frequently accessed data in memory, is one of the most important aspects of MySQL tuning. The goal is to keep the working set in memory. In most cases, this should be between 60%-90% of available memory on a dedicated database host, but depends on many factors.

links.title: Tuning the InnoDB Buffer Pool Size

panels.title: InnoDB Buffer Pool Size

panels.description:
**InnoDB Buffer Pool Size % of Total RAM**

InnoDB maintains a storage area called the buffer pool for caching data and indexes in memory.  Knowing how the InnoDB buffer pool works, and taking advantage of it to keep frequently accessed data in memory, is one of the most important aspects of MySQL tuning. The goal is to keep the working set in memory. In most cases, this should be between 60%-90% of available memory on a dedicated database host, but depends on many factors.

links.title: Tuning the InnoDB Buffer Pool Size

panels.title: Buffer Pool Size of Total RAM

panels.description:
**Max Connections** 

Max Connections is the maximum permitted number of simultaneous client connections. By default, this is 151. Increasing this value increases the number of file descriptors that mysqld requires. If the required number of descriptors are not available, the server reduces the value of Max Connections.

mysqld actually permits Max Connections + 1 clients to connect. The extra connection is reserved for use by accounts that have the SUPER privilege, such as root.

Max Used Connections is the maximum number of connections that have been in use simultaneously since the server started.

Connections is the number of connection attempts (successful or not) to the MySQL server.
panels.title: MySQL Connections

panels.description:
**MySQL Active Threads**

Threads Connected is the number of open connections, while Threads Running is the number of threads not sleeping.
panels.title: MySQL Client Thread Activity

panels.description:
**MySQL Questions**

The number of statements executed by the server. This includes only statements sent to the server by clients and not statements executed within stored programs, unlike the Queries used in the QPS calculation. 

This variable does not count the following commands:
* ``COM_PING``
* ``COM_STATISTICS``
* ``COM_STMT_PREPARE``
* ``COM_STMT_CLOSE``
* ``COM_STMT_RESET``
panels.title: MySQL Questions

panels.description:
**MySQL Thread Cache**

The thread_cache_size variable sets how many threads the server should cache to reuse. When a client disconnects, the client's threads are put in the cache if the cache is not full. It is autosized in MySQL 5.6.8 and above (capped to 100). Requests for threads are satisfied by reusing threads taken from the cache if possible, and only when the cache is empty is a new thread created.

* *Threads_created*: The number of threads created to handle connections.
* *Threads_cached*: The number of threads in the thread cache.
panels.title: MySQL Thread Cache

panels.description:
**MySQL Select Types**

As with most relational databases, selecting based on indexes is more efficient than scanning an entire table's data. Here we see the counters for selects not done with indexes.

* ***Select Scan*** is how many queries caused full table scans, in which all the data in the table had to be read and either discarded or returned.
* ***Select Range*** is how many queries used a range scan, which means MySQL scanned all rows in a given range.
* ***Select Full Join*** is the number of joins that are not joined on an index, this is usually a huge performance hit.
panels.title: MySQL Select Types

panels.description:
**MySQL Sorts**

Due to a query's structure, order, or other requirements, MySQL sorts the rows before returning them. For example, if a table is ordered 1 to 10 but you want the results reversed, MySQL then has to sort the rows to return 10 to 1.

This graph also shows when sorts had to scan a whole table or a given range of a table in order to return the results and which could not have been sorted via an index.
panels.title: MySQL Sorts

panels.description:
**MySQL Slow Queries**

Slow queries are defined as queries being slower than the long_query_time setting. For example, if you have long_query_time set to 3, all queries that take longer than 3 seconds to complete will show on this graph.
panels.title: MySQL Slow Queries

panels.description:
**Aborted Connections**

When a given host connects to MySQL and the connection is interrupted in the middle (for example due to bad credentials), MySQL keeps that info in a system table (since 5.6 this table is exposed in performance_schema).

If the amount of failed requests without a successful connection reaches the value of max_connect_errors, mysqld assumes that something is wrong and blocks the host from further connection.

To allow connections from that host again, you need to issue the ``FLUSH HOSTS`` statement.
panels.title: MySQL Aborted Connections

panels.description:
**Table Locks**

MySQL takes a number of different locks for varying reasons. In this graph we see how many Table level locks MySQL has requested from the storage engine. In the case of InnoDB, many times the locks could actually be row locks as it only takes table level locks in a few specific cases.

It is most useful to compare Locks Immediate and Locks Waited. If Locks waited is rising, it means you have lock contention. Otherwise, Locks Immediate rising and falling is normal activity.
panels.title: MySQL Table Locks

panels.description:
**MySQL Network Traffic**

Here we can see how much network traffic is generated by MySQL. Outbound is network traffic sent from MySQL and Inbound is network traffic MySQL has received.
panels.title: MySQL Network Traffic

panels.description:
**MySQL Network Usage Hourly**

Here we can see how much network traffic is generated by MySQL per hour. You can use the bar graph to compare data sent by MySQL and data received by MySQL.
panels.title: MySQL Network Usage Hourly

panels.description:
***System Memory***: Total Memory for the system.\
***InnoDB Buffer Pool Data***: InnoDB maintains a storage area called the buffer pool for caching data and indexes in memory.\
***TokuDB Cache Size***: Similar in function to the InnoDB Buffer Pool,  TokuDB will allocate 50% of the installed RAM for its own cache.\
***Key Buffer Size***: Index blocks for MYISAM tables are buffered and are shared by all threads. key_buffer_size is the size of the buffer used for index blocks.\
***Adaptive Hash Index Size***: When InnoDB notices that some index values are being accessed very frequently, it builds a hash index for them in memory on top of B-Tree indexes.\
 ***Query Cache Size***: The query cache stores the text of a SELECT statement together with the corresponding result that was sent to the client. The query cache has huge scalability problems in that only one thread can do an operation in the query cache at the same time.\
***InnoDB Dictionary Size***: The data dictionary is InnoDB ‘s internal catalog of tables. InnoDB stores the data dictionary on disk, and loads entries into memory while the server is running.\
***InnoDB Log Buffer Size***: The MySQL InnoDB log buffer allows transactions to run without having to write the log to disk before the transactions commit.
panels.title: MySQL Internal Memory Overview

panels.description:
**Top Command Counters**

The Com_{{xxx}} statement counter variables indicate the number of times each xxx statement has been executed. There is one status variable for each type of statement. For example, Com_delete and Com_update count [``DELETE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/delete.html) and [``UPDATE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/update.html) statements, respectively. Com_delete_multi and Com_update_multi are similar but apply to [``DELETE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/delete.html) and [``UPDATE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/update.html) statements that use multiple-table syntax.
panels.title: Top Command Counters

panels.description:
**Top Command Counters Hourly**

The Com_{{xxx}} statement counter variables indicate the number of times each xxx statement has been executed. There is one status variable for each type of statement. For example, Com_delete and Com_update count [``DELETE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/delete.html) and [``UPDATE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/update.html) statements, respectively. Com_delete_multi and Com_update_multi are similar but apply to [``DELETE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/delete.html) and [``UPDATE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/update.html) statements that use multiple-table syntax.
panels.title: Top Command Counters Hourly

panels.description:
**MySQL Handlers**

Handler statistics are internal statistics on how MySQL is selecting, updating, inserting, and modifying rows, tables, and indexes.

This is in fact the layer between the Storage Engine and MySQL.

* `read_rnd_next` is incremented when the server performs a full table scan and this is a counter you don't really want to see with a high value.
* `read_key` is incremented when a read is done with an index.
* `read_next` is incremented when the storage engine is asked to 'read the next index entry'. A high value means a lot of index scans are being done.
panels.title: MySQL Handlers

panels.description:
**MySQL Query Cache Memory**

The query cache has huge scalability problems in that only one thread can do an operation in the query cache at the same time. This serialization is true not only for SELECTs, but also for INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE.

This also means that the larger the `query_cache_size` is set to, the slower those operations become. In concurrent environments, the MySQL Query Cache quickly becomes a contention point, decreasing performance. MariaDB and AWS Aurora have done work to try and eliminate the query cache contention in their flavors of MySQL, while MySQL 8.0 has eliminated the query cache feature.

The recommended settings for most environments is to set:
  ``query_cache_type=0``
  ``query_cache_size=0``

Note that while you can dynamically change these values, to completely remove the contention point you have to restart the database.
panels.title: MySQL Query Cache Memory

panels.description:
**MySQL Query Cache Activity**

The query cache has huge scalability problems in that only one thread can do an operation in the query cache at the same time. This serialization is true not only for SELECTs, but also for INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE.

This also means that the larger the `query_cache_size` is set to, the slower those operations become. In concurrent environments, the MySQL Query Cache quickly becomes a contention point, decreasing performance. MariaDB and AWS Aurora have done work to try and eliminate the query cache contention in their flavors of MySQL, while MySQL 8.0 has eliminated the query cache feature.

The recommended settings for most environments is to set:
``query_cache_type=0``
``query_cache_size=0``

Note that while you can dynamically change these values, to completely remove the contention point you have to restart the database.
panels.title: MySQL Query Cache Activity

panels.description:
**MySQL Table Open Cache Status**

The recommendation is to set the `table_open_cache_instances` to a loose correlation to virtual CPUs, keeping in mind that more instances means the cache is split more times. If you have a cache set to 500 but it has 10 instances, each cache will only have 50 cached.

The `table_definition_cache` and `table_open_cache` can be left as default as they are auto-sized MySQL 5.6 and above (ie: do not set them to any value).
panels.title: MySQL Table Open Cache Status

panels.description:
**MySQL Open Tables**

The recommendation is to set the `table_open_cache_instances` to a loose correlation to virtual CPUs, keeping in mind that more instances means the cache is split more times. If you have a cache set to 500 but it has 10 instances, each cache will only have 50 cached.

The `table_definition_cache` and `table_open_cache` can be left as default as they are auto-sized MySQL 5.6 and above (ie: do not set them to any value).
panels.title: MySQL Open Tables

panels.description:
**MySQL Table Definition Cache**

The recommendation is to set the `table_open_cache_instances` to a loose correlation to virtual CPUs, keeping in mind that more instances means the cache is split more times. If you have a cache set to 500 but it has 10 instances, each cache will only have 50 cached.

The `table_definition_cache` and `table_open_cache` can be left as default as they are auto-sized MySQL 5.6 and above (ie: do not set them to any value).
panels.title: MySQL Table Definition Cache

targets.expr: clamp_max(((avg by (mode) ( (clamp_max(rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{instance="$host",mode!="idle"}[$interval]),1)) or (clamp_max(irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{instance="$host",mode!="idle"}[5m]),1)) ))*100 or (avg_over_time(node_cpu_seconds_total_average{instance=~"$host", mode!="total", mode!="idle"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_cpu_seconds_total_average{instance=~"$host", mode!="total", mode!="idle"}[5m]))),100)

sum((rate(node_disk_read_time_seconds_total{device!~"dm-.+", instance="$host"}[$interval]) / rate(node_disk_reads_completed_total{device!~"dm-.+", instance="$host"}[$interval])) or (irate(node_disk_read_time_seconds_total{device!~"dm-.+", instance="$host"}[5m]) / irate(node_disk_reads_completed_total{device!~"dm-.+", instance="$host"}[5m]))
or avg_over_time(aws_rds_read_latency_average{instance="$host"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(aws_rds_read_latency_average{instance="$host"}[5m]))

sum((rate(node_disk_write_time_seconds_total{device!~"dm-.+", instance="$host"}[$interval]) / rate(node_disk_writes_completed_total{device!~"dm-.+", instance="$host"}[$interval])) or (irate(node_disk_write_time_seconds_total{device!~"dm-.+", instance="$host"}[5m]) / irate(node_disk_writes_completed_total{device!~"dm-.+", instance="$host"}[5m])) or 
avg_over_time(aws_rds_write_latency_average{instance="$host"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(aws_rds_write_latency_average{instance="$host"}[5m]))
